title: Part 7
content:
Part 7

CHILDREN TEND TO forget most of their memories from early childhood, such as at ages one or two.

This phenomenon was apparently called childhood amnesia.

The earliest memories people could usually recall were from around the age of three.

However, it wasn't that infants couldn't form memories at all.

Some people could remember their early childhood in detail.

The proof laid in the child in front of me, who was able to remember everything.

"…Perfect."

To him, it was merely verbalizing his recalled memories.

However, it was something most people couldn't do.

There was the experiment with gummies when he was two and the subsequent curriculum.

It was a casual exchange on the playground. Kiyotaka selectively saved necessary memories.

I remember it so vividly that I almost want to dismiss it as a child's fantasy.

After hearing about Kiyotaka's past seven years, Tabuchi and the others in front of me were greatly excited.

"If we publish these research findings, it will turn the academic world upside down… It's incredible, Ayanokouji-sensei. Your child has achieved results that are completely different from other children."

"Tabuchi, whether he's my child doesn't matter. Just tell me plainly how amazing it is."

"Yes, sir. It has been proven that learning and memory are possible while a baby is in the womb. However, the learning ability during infancy is considered very immature and unstable, and it's believed that memories can't be solidified. Or perhaps, the memories are stored but become buried and unsearchable as development progresses. It was thought to be one of these two scenarios. However, your son… I mean, Kiyotaka can search them effortlessly."

"So? How does that translate to excellence?"

"For instance, even if we only consider the three years from ages zero to three, it would mean having a memory advantage of 1095 days. Of course, it's not as simple as that, but it's safe to say that the secret to his overwhelmingly high learning ability is also tied to this."

Even when the children started side by side, by the time they were three, a significant gap in their abilities developed.

"He's definitely a genius!"

It was in a researcher's nature to speak with such a spirited demeanor—as if the excitement hadn't worn off yet.

However, we couldn't simply rejoice in this.

The term "genius" alone would negate the purpose of the White Room.

"Unfortunately, neither Kiyotaka's mother nor I are particularly bright. In that sense, it can't directly be linked to genetics, but we can't completely deny the possibility that a mutation occurred, can we?"

"That's… true. Genetics haven't been fully deciphered yet."

"Listen, our goal isn't to find geniuses from the moment they're born. No matter how poor the DNA, our aim is to nurture them into excellence."

Indeed, it was a good thing that such an entity had emerged.

However, it would've been better if it were not my own child.

A third-party perspective would misunderstand, thinking that I had given my own child special education.

The children within his generation, despite having received the same curriculum, mostly turned into useless junk, which was regrettable.

I issued instructions and sent Kiyotaka back to the other fourth-generation students.

I had planned to show the fourth generation's current state to the visiting Sakayanagi.

"It might be a good idea to make the other children aware of his existence to foster competition, helping to improve the others' abilities. It would be stimulating for them, especially for the children competing for the top spot in each generation."

Indeed, having big goals was never a bad thing. Being on top in a small environment could potentially stunt your potential growth.

Many researchers, including Ishida, agreed with this opinion.

However, Suzukake raised a dissenting voice.

"It's not a bad idea. I also think goals are important. However, if the goal is unreachable, it's meaningless. There's just too big a gap between Kiyotaka and the other children."

"…That's a valid point."

"It's important for the goal to be set high yet achievable. We should control the information disclosed here and make his abilities seem lower than they actually are. Even then, the top children might doubt his existence, but we should only show them indirect evidence of his actual existence."

The rest would automatically foster a competitive spirit in a world where they never meet.

"Do as you like, but make sure you continue the necessary education for the remaining fourth-generation students without favoring Kiyotaka."

"Even if the number of dropouts continues to increase?"

"Yes. I don't mind if Kiyotaka gets crushed. If we see results beyond our expectations, it will allow us to establish a safeguard for when more talented generations emerge."

I must not let myself be satisfied with immediate results and aim for greater heights instead.

If my son were to be crushed in the process, I might gather some sympathy from the outside.

I would continue to demonstrate my passion for this project.

"The fourth-generation students are undergoing the Beta curriculum, but there are concerns. This harsh education might mentally mature them too quickly."

Suzukake commented, and Tabuchi immediately began to explain further.

"By the time they reach middle and high school age, they might have the mental age of someone in their twenties… no, nearly thirties. This, coupled with their ignorance of the world, might also reveal their extremely childish side."

Perhaps the extremes were too much.

"At some point, we'll need a different approach. The question is whether they can learn and grow through their own will. However, that's a big gamble. Being heavily influenced by the outside could drastically reduce their value as works of art."

Suzukake, as the one leading the charge so far, had a serious, stern expression.

That alone was proof of the challenging events he was facing.

"Excuse me. Sakayanagi-sama is in the observation room as scheduled… What should we do?"

It's about time I head there, though…

"Let him observe for a while longer. Also, keep the curriculum we're showing him as harmless as planned. Showing something too stimulating might cause backlash."

I stood up, but instead of immediately heading to Sakayanagi, I went to the surveillance room.

I then turned on the audio of the surveillance camera capturing the observation room. Sakayanagi was in a neutral position, but his stance could shift to the enemy's side at any moment.

It was a low likelihood, but I couldn't completely rule out that he was scouting the White Room.

First, I would have to assess how much of a risk this was.

Through the screen, I saw Sakayanagi and a girl held in his arms—she seemed to be his daughter.

Both were watching the White Room students through a one-way mirror.

"Look, Arisu. These children might someday be responsible for Japan's future."

From what it appeared, it wasn't the father's idea to prompt the visit.

She placed her hands on the glass as if to peer inside, staring intently at the sight.

She did it without growing tired, for five, then ten minutes.

"What's the matter, Arisu? It's rare to see you so interested in something."

"An experiment to artificially create geniuses. How could I not be interested?"

"…As expected, that's not something a child would say."

Nothing seemed artificial between the father and daughter.

"But, aren't there various problems with this experiment?"

"Like what?"

"From a humanitarian perspective, people are likely to criticize it from all sides."

"Ha, haha…"

All things considered, the child had a calmness and an adult-like perspective and sensibility that belied her young age.

"Above all, I can't imagine creating geniuses artificially. Even if someone outstanding emerges from this facility, can we truly say it's a result of the experiment?"

I had planned to meet them after reaching some conclusions, but I became interested in his daughter, Arisu Sakayanagi's perspective.

A child's take on the evaluation of the White Room wasn't something you heard often.

"Why do you think that?"

"Ultimately, I think the children who stand out just have excellent DNA."

"I see. Indeed, the curriculum they undergo is very strict. The children who end up surviving might be excellent to begin with. You really are intelligent, just like her. And your personality too."

"I'm glad. Being compared to my mother is the highest praise for me."

It was hard to determine where the line between genius and mediocrity laid.

"Genes" and "environment"—these were precisely the important factors needed in human development.

It was true that not all children growing up in the White Room environment started with inferior genes.

"After all, even if there are children who survive the curriculum, they're just blessed with their parents' talents."

Sakayanagi seemed genuinely perplexed by a question that even adults couldn't answer immediately.

"Well, that might be true, or it might not. I don't know. However, I can't dismiss the possibility that these children are destined to carry our future."

He explained his thoughts, but his daughter didn't seem very interested.

She was now looking at the White Room children even more intently than before.

"…That child, he's been handling all the tasks calmly and effortlessly since earlier."

"Ah, he's Sensei's son. His name was… Ayanokouji… Kiyotaka-kun, I believe."

It seemed she had already noticed the unusual aura Kiyotaka emitted.

"If he's Sensei's child, then he must have excellent DNA, right?"

"I wonder. At least, Sensei didn't graduate from a prestigious university, and he doesn't have any exceptional athletic skills. His wife is really ordinary too. Additionally, neither of their grandparents had outstanding talents. However, Sensei had more ambition and indomitable spirit than anyone else. That's how he was able to become so important. At one point, he even tried to influence the country."

"Then… is he the ideal subject for this experiment?"

"Yes… For that person, he'd be the ideal child. However… from my point of view, I can't help but feel sorry for him."

"Why?"

"He's spent his entire life in this facility since he was born. The first thing he saw wasn't his mother or father, but the facility's white ceiling. If he had dropped out early, he might've lived with Sensei. No, it's precisely because he's able to remain here that he continues to receive Sensei's favor… If so, then it could mean that the facility's ultimate goal is to raise all the children it educates into geniuses. However, for now, it's still in its experimental stage. It's a fight that'll be decided fifty, or even a hundred years from now. The children here are not living to showcase their talents by the time they become adults; they exist for the sake of future children. Both the survivors and the dropouts are just part of that sampling."

"Do you dislike this facility, Father?"

A question that hit the core of the matter, one that I wanted to ask myself, came flying from his daughter.

Depending on the response, I might have to make various considerations…

"Hm…? I'm not sure… I can't honestly support it. If the children raised here turn out to be more excellent than anyone else, if this facility becomes the norm—I think that would be the beginning of misfortune."

There was no apparent connection to Kijima.

Only Sakayanagi's typical good-natured answer returned.

"Rest assured. I will shatter it. I will prove that a genius is not determined by their education, but by the moment they're born."

"Yes. I'm looking forward to it, Arisu."

The father smiled happily as he stroked his daughter's head, apparently with no hidden agenda.

"By the way, Father. I think I'll try to learn chess…"

I then turned off the camera's audio and stood up.

"It was an unnecessary concern."

Though, it was better to be safe than sorry.

As the time for the announcement approached, no one knew what might happen.

toc.label: Chapter 6: Hopelessness and a Way of Life
